TopicTitle: How do I make a stock bearing in ksp?

Articles.Content:
Hi There People,

I have recently been looking at how to make a stock bearing in ksp (for a challenge) and I was looking around the forums but there was no tutorial to be found on it.

Not to be a bit annoying but I was wondering if one of you guys could make a tutorial in the tutorial section of the forums.

Thanks,

Burn

Edited February 22, 2014 by burnoutforzai

Well, you just make an assembly with a hole in it that surrounds the part you're using as the axle. There are a bunch of ways to do this, like with various structural pieces, lander legs, those blue stack separator rings, etc. The spinning assembly and the axle have to start out connected by some sort of decoupler.

The main problem with stock bearings is that once you separate the parts with the decoupler, you have no physical connection between them anymore, meaning you now have 2 separate ships (if both parts have control parts) or 1 ship and 1 piece of uncontrollable debris. So you have to take that into account in the design, depending on what you're trying to do with it.

There are probably better ways of making stock bearings but the above has worked for me in the very limited applications I had for them.

This ancient post shows up first when you search Google for "ksp stock bearing" and  while the answer is technically correct, the result will be beyond doubt complex, troublesome and take a lot of work to get right. Finding a comprehensive, competent manual takes quite a bit of time, so let me provide a link to one.

This video shows one neat and simple stock bearing based on Stayputniks clipped into Mk0 tanks, which are placed inside Mk1 structural fuselage; the fuselage is capped with a Z-1000 battery, sandwiched between the bearing and a reaction wheel attached to the rotor but offset far enough not to clip into the battery; the RW acts as a motor too. The axle (Mk0 tanks) and the tube (fuselage) are connected with a separator which explodes upon separation.
